summary: Once I stepped in a Rhaegar Lives fic in the Rhaegar/Lyanna tag that portrayed him as some maniatic that was cruel at Lyanna...
question: Once I stepped in a Rhaegar Lives fic in the Rhaegar/Lyanna tag that portrayed him as some maniatic that was cruel at Lyanna because Jon wasn't a girl and I was like... Please tell me the book part where it says that he would be angry at her for that. He said: the dragons has three heads, not the dragons have to be two females and a male.
answer: Oh yes that’s a popular idea they have. They’ll write ~metas~ claiming that Rhaegar would absolutely hate Jon because he is not a girl, and hate Lyanna too because she delivered a boy instead of a girl. They completely mischaracterize Rhaegar and live in their AU fanfiction world in which Martin’s original characters are nothing like their true selves. Even if Rhaegar believed his child by Lyanna would be a girl (which is still only a theory), there is no evidence or hints whatsoever that he would react negatively toward a boy. Rhaegar is canonically kind and honorable, and to believe him capable of resenting hatred toward his own child is a fallacy. Prophecies are tricky to understand, there should be room left for interpretation, and Rhaegar knows that like no one else. He was conceived for the sake of that prophecy, and he’s been studying it since he was a child. If Rhaegar believed his third child would be a daughter, but it happened to be a son, he would simply accept that his original thought was erroneous. And love Jon with all his heart.

summary: It’s crazy to think only one person in Jon Snow’s family never changed who he was to him; Uncle Benjen.
body:
It’s crazy to think only one person in Jon Snow’s family never changed who he was to him; Uncle Benjen.

Father becomes uncle

Aunt becomes mother

Sisters & brothers become cousins

Lover (ew) becomes aunt

Uncle Benjen stayed Uncle Benjen.

summary: Jon Snow is probably the first „highborn“ who believes in the character Daenerys Targaryen. He didn‘t bent the knee because she...
body:
Jon Snow is probably the first „highborn“ who believes in the character Daenerys Targaryen. He didn‘t bent the knee because she is a Targaryen or because of her beauty or her dragons. Dany is used to people bending the knee to her whenever she appears or does something magical (Dragon hatching, going through fire). Sure, Tyrion and Jorah wouldn’t follow her if she would be a terrible and mad person, but Jon is the first person who is NOT impressed by her dragons and her many titles. He wants to see Daenerys character first and if she is a good person who will sacrifice herself for the greater good. After she saved him beyond the wall and told him that she will wait reclaiming her throne and will help killing the Night King he saw the true Daenerys. He saw the Daenerys who is willing to risk her life to save the people of Westeros.


That’s the moment when Jon realizes that Daenerys is worthy of his loyalty. And the reason why she reacted so emotional is because this is special for Daenerys.

That was the first time Daenerys has really earned loyality by herself. Not because of her dragons, her army or her titles. But because of her doing and her decision. That‘s also why Jon and Dany fell in love. They see each others as equals.

And I think this is very beautiful.

summary: The more I think about it the more I think that Ned's choice to raise Jon as his bastard was a pretty selfish one. If he wanted...
question: The more I think about it the more I think that Ned's choice to raise Jon as his bastard was a pretty selfish one. If he wanted to keep Jon safely out of Robert's notice he could have asked someone he absolutely trusted- Howland Reed- to raise Jon & or passed him as Benjen's. Ned talks about the price he pays for his lies but HE doesn't pay at all Cat, Jon and his kids do. Am I totally off the mark?
answer:
Not to me! Maybe I’m off the mark too, but I don’t understand Ned’s choices in raising Jon. I know he wanted to keep him close to protect him but that also keeps him there to be scrutinized by one and all, as opposed to provided for but safely out of sight and mind. I don’t get why no plans for Jon were made among those he trusted, for his future. People looooove blaming Catelyn for Jon signing his life away at the Wall but why on earth should she be obligated to keep her husband’s bastard? Ned was his father, he was the one with a duty to him, he was the one who should have arranged something- anything- for him in the North yet he did nothing. He let him join a group of criminals, rapists and murderers just so he wouldn’t have to deal with the “you’re actually a Targ” bit, and presumably so Jon couldn’t do anything with that knowledge. Had his wife live with insult of his presence of him in her home for fourteen years so Jon could be brought up as his son yet he didn’t have faith that he raised him better than that?

Yeah, then there’s that bit about how Ned could never burden another with Jon, which takes Howland and Benjen off the table, but he’s fine with burdening his wife. With humiliating, shaming and breaking her heart. How is it any better? Nobody did what Ned did, no man brought their bastard home to his wife yet none of this is ever laid at his feet; Catelyn is instead made the villain for being cold and resentful, even while other women would have smothered him in his sleep. Honorable Neddy won’t put anyone else in danger but hey, he’ll put the lives of Catelyn and the kids at risk every day by keeping Jon under their roof, knowing the consequences should Robert find out, but because it’s Ned, it’s all about his great sacrifice and how amazing he is, like he hasn’t set up his unassuming family to be ruined alongside him. I guess more than the actual text, it’s how fans respond to him and this whole situation that irks me than anything else.

I know his heart is in the right place and it all comes from love but I can’t help as see it as selfish too. I’m just not down with the popular opinion of a perfect, tragically heroic Ned. He failed Catelyn and while I think he did more for Jon than anyone else would have (and I would expect Jon to rightly feel true gratitude once the pain of discovering his parentage fades), I still think he could’ve handled it better and spared them a lot of hurt. He had a bunch of shitty options, I know, but I can’t help feel he chose one of the worst, with only one set of promises in mind.

summary: I am genuinely fond of the Blackfish, but I thought him an unfair jerk when he told Jaime he didn't trust Jon Snow because his...
question: I am genuinely fond of the Blackfish, but I thought him an unfair jerk when he told Jaime he didn't trust Jon Snow because his precious niece Catelyn didn't - how can you judge someone you've never met?
answer:
First, because he trusts Catelyn’s judgment, since Catelyn’s judgment is usually good. It’s very much not when it comes to Jon, but as you say, the Blackfish hasn’t met Jon and can’t possibly know just how bad Catelyn’s blind spot there is.

Second, because Westerosi society is deeply anti-bastard. Specifically, bastards are considered to be treachery-prone and resentful.

They still think me a turncloak. That was a bitter draft to drink, but Jon could not blame them. He was a bastard, after all. Everyone knew that bastards were wanton and treacherous by nature, having been born of lust and deceit.

- Jon VII, ASoS

Bastard children were born from lust and lies, men said; their nature was wanton and treacherous. 

- Jon X, ASoS

“All my lovely dromonds.” Cersei almost laughed. “My lord father used to say that bastards are treacherous by nature. Would that I had listened.”

- Cersei X, AFFC

[Alys] blushed. “So I could meet your brother. Oh, there was some other pretext, but that was the real reason. I was almost of an age with Robb, and my father thought we might make a match. There was a feast. I danced with you and your brother both. He was very courteous and said that I danced beautifully. You were sullen. My father said that was to be expected in a bastard.”

- Jon IX, ADWD

It’s a long-held opinion, appearing in material set before the main series as well.

“The old High Septon told my father that king’s laws are one thing, and the laws of the gods another,” the boy said stubbornly. “Trueborn children are made in a marriage bed and blessed by the Father and the Mother, but bastards are born of lust and weakness, he said. King Aegon decreed that his bastards were not bastards, but he could not change their nature. The High Septon said all bastards are born to betrayal … Daemon Blackfyre, Bittersteel, even Bloodraven. Lord Rivers was more cunning than the other two, he said, but in the end he would prove himself a traitor, too. The High Septon counseled my father never to put any trust in him, nor in any other bastards, great or small.”

Born to betrayal, Dunk thought. Born of lust and weakness. Never to be trusted, great or small. “Egg,” he said, “didn’t you ever think that I might be a bastard?”

- The Sworn Sword

“Bittersteel be buggered,” insisted a familiar voice. “No bastard can be trusted, not even him. A few victories will bring him over the water fast enough.”

- The Mystery Knight

The dragonseeds Ulf White and Hugh Hammer had gone over to the enemy … but were they the only traitors in their midst? What of Addam of Hull and the girl Nettles? They had been born of bastard stock as well. Could they be trusted?

Lord Bartimos Celtigar thought not. “Bastards are treacherous by nature,” he said. “It is in their blood. Betrayal comes as easily to a bastard as loyalty to trueborn men.” 

- The Princess and the Queen

Looks like Brynden Tully’s absorbed some of those broadly held beliefs about bastards.

This is all compounded by the fact that allowing Brynden to take the black and serve under Jon Snow is an offer of relative and suspicious mercy from the notoriously untrustworthy Jaime. From Brynden’s perspective, what’s more likely? That normally-astute Catelyn’s wrong about a young man she’s known all his life, or that Jaime Lannister’s word is good?

There was a feast. I danced with you and your brother both. He was very courteous and said that I danced beautifully. You were sullen. My father said that was to be expected in a bastard.”

- Jon IX, ADWD

It’s a long-held opinion, appearing in material set before the main series as well.

“The old High Septon told my father that king’s laws are one thing, and the laws of the gods another,” the boy said stubbornly. “Trueborn children are made in a marriage bed and blessed by the Father and the Mother, but bastards are born of lust and weakness, he said. King Aegon decreed that his bastards were not bastards, but he could not change their nature. The High Septon said all bastards are born to betrayal … Daemon Blackfyre, Bittersteel, even Bloodraven. Lord Rivers was more cunning than the other two, he said, but in the end he would prove himself a traitor, too. The High Septon counseled my father never to put any trust in him, nor in any other bastards, great or small.”

Born to betrayal, Dunk thought. Born of lust and weakness. Never to be trusted, great or small. “Egg,” he said, “didn’t you ever think that I might be a bastard?”

- The Sworn Sword

“Bittersteel be buggered,” insisted a familiar voice. “No bastard can be trusted, not even him. A few victories will bring him over the water fast enough.”

- The Mystery Knight

The dragonseeds Ulf White and Hugh Hammer had gone over to the enemy … but were they the only traitors in their midst? What of Addam of Hull and the girl Nettles? They had been born of bastard stock as well. Could they be trusted?

Lord Bartimos Celtigar thought not. “Bastards are treacherous by nature,” he said. “It is in their blood. Betrayal comes as easily to a bastard as loyalty to trueborn men.” 

- The Princess and the Queen

Looks like Brynden Tully’s absorbed some of those broadly held beliefs about bastards.

This is all compounded by the fact that allowing Brynden to take the black and serve under Jon Snow is an offer of relative and suspicious mercy from the notoriously untrustworthy Jaime. From Brynden’s perspective, what’s more likely? That normally-astute Catelyn’s wrong about a young man she’s known all his life, or that Jaime Lannister’s word is good?

First, because he trusts Catelyn’s judgment, since Catelyn’s judgment is usually good. It’s very much not when it comes to Jon, but as you say, the Blackfish hasn’t met Jon and can’t possibly know just how bad Catelyn’s blind spot there is.

Second, because Westerosi society is deeply anti-bastard. Specifically, bastards are considered to be treachery-prone and resentful.

They still think me a turncloak. That was a bitter draft to drink, but Jon could not blame them. He was a bastard, after all. Everyone knew that bastards were wanton and treacherous by nature, having been born of lust and deceit.

- Jon VII, ASoS

body:
When the mind wonders…

There are two things I think will ultimately be connected and important to Game of Thrones’ endgame:


1. The Night King and Jon share something special, and it’s not just that they are connected by Stark blood or have died, but the Night King was created by being stabbed in the heart with dragon glass. Who else has seen death and transformation via a stab to the heart🧐


2. “You know nothing, Jon Snow.” Why does this echo so often across seasons? Why is it connected to being a “Northern fool?” I do subscribe to Political Jon theory and I suspect that the Northern Fool knows more than he’s letting on. Also, is it just me or do you really believe he only saw darkness on the other side of death? 🧐


Sorry for the morning meta compilation… coffee is just starting to take effect…

summary: If Lady Stoneheart ran into Jon (maybe if he was the obe sent with the wight to Kings Landing? Somehow, idk, just go with it)...
question: If Lady Stoneheart ran into Jon (maybe if he was the obe sent with the wight to Kings Landing? Somehow, idk, just go with it) would she try to kill him?
answer:
I… um… are you mixing up the show and the books here? What wight sent to King’s Landing?

Jon could go south for lots of reasons, or he might never do so. Lady Stoneheart might try to kill anyone, she’s not rational.

@kitsunesongs replied:

Nope! The wight’s hand from clash of kings that was sent to kings landing and Tyrion laughed off - basically, it was the only reason I could think of for Jon to be in the south. 

The wight’s hand was sent south in AGOT, rotted away in ACOK, and Alliser Thorne (the NW sent to KL) was on his way back to the Wall months before the Red Wedding and Catelyn’s death and resurrection. Why would Jon be in the south, to skip his entire northern storyline and all the character development that goes with it? Why would Jeor Mormont send a boy trainee to King’s Landing, the bastard of a just-executed traitor, the complete opposite of the reasons he sent Thorne? I can’t “just go with it”, it doesn’t make any sense at all. Any other reason would make more sense for Jon to go south when/where Stoneheart is present.

And yeah Lady Stoneheart is not rational - that’s why I’m asking if she would try to kill Jon if she saw him, like she would a Frey or Lannister, or just ignore him, because the part of her that cared about Ned’s bastard (the part of her that loved Ned) is pretty much gone…

I think Stoneheart is so irrational she might attempt to kill her loved ones (just look at Brienne ffs), so yeah, um… yeah. Caring or not caring is not really relevant, any feeling could be twisted to “deserve” death.

summary: every time Jon Snow said the word “but”in S7 If you don’t know why this is relevant, well, lucky you. I’ve been doing a season 7...
body:
every time Jon Snow said the word “but”in S7

If you don’t know why this is relevant, well, lucky you.

I’ve been doing a season 7 re-watch just for entertainment purposes, but (!) in light of recent ~discourse~ I decided to take note of the times Jon said the word “but.” This was a stretch for me. It’s not the but(t) I’m usually interested in when it comes to Jon Snow. And yet, I soldiered on. You can all thank me later. 

Now, onward! Oh and credit to @kitsn0w for the gorgeous gif of Jon ducking Drogon and the last one of Jon’s glorious bum. The other crappy gifs are my sad attempts.

7x01

Addressing Tormund about the Wall.

Jon: “I’m not the king of the freefolk, but if we’re going to survive this winter together—”

Tormund: “You want us to man the castles for you?”

Jon argues against Sansa’s proposed punishment of the Karstark and Umber children.

Jon: “My father said, the man who passes the sentence should swing the sword, and I have tried to live by those words. But I will not punish a son for his father’s sins, and I will not take a family home away from a family it has belonged to for centuries.”

After the tension in the great hall, Sansa and Jon argue yet again.

Jon: “You are my sister, but I am king now.”

Sansa (mocking): “Will you start wearing a crown?”

Jon: “When you question my decisions in front of the other lords and ladies, you undermine me.”

Sansa: “So we can’t question your decisions?”

Jon: “Of course you can, but–”

Sansa: “Joffrey never let anyone question his authority. You think he was a good king?”

7x02

Jon receives a summons to Dragonstone (from Tyrion on behalf of Daenerys).

Sansa (to Davos): “You’re not suggesting Jon meet with her!”

Davos: “No, too dangerous.”

Jon: “But?”

Davos: “If the army of the dead make it past the wall, do we have enough men to fight them?”

Jon explains to the northern/vale nobility why he has to go to Dragonstone.

Sansa: “This isn’t an invitation, it’s a trap.”

Jon: “It could be. But I don’t believe Tyrion would do that.”

Even Lady Lyanna Mormont urges him not to go. Look at how sad this makes him!

Jon: “You all crowned me your king. I never wanted it. I never asked for it. But I accepted it because the north is my home. It is a part of me and I will never stop fighting for it, no matter the odds. But the odds are against us. None of you have seen the army of the dead. None of you. We can never hope to defeat them alone. We need allies – powerful allies. I know it’s a risk. But I have to take it.”

7x03

Tyrion reflects on Jon’s decision to come to Dragonstone.

Tyrion: “General rule of thumb: Stark men don’t fare well when they travel south.”

Jon: “True. But I’m not a Stark.”

Drogon: 

Jon and Davos meet with Daenerys.

Davos: “You could storm King’s Landing tomorrow and the city would fall. Hell, we almost took it, and we didn’t have dragons.”

Tyrion: “Almost.”

Jon: “But you haven’t stormed King’s Landing. Why not? The only reason I can see is that you don’t want to kill thousands of innocent people. It’s the fastest way to win the war, but you won’t do it. Which means, at the very least, you’re better than Cersei.”

Jon still won’t bend the knee

Jon: “I mean no offense, Your Grace. But I don’t know you.”

(rest behind a cut, because Jon says “but” a LOT.)

7x04

Dany, having suffered a significant loss in her war against Cersei, demands advice from Jon.

Dany: “What do you think I should do.”

Jon: “I never thought dragons would exist again. No one did. The oeople who follow you know you made something impossible happen. Maybe that helps them believe you can make other impossible things happen. Build world that’s different from the shit one they’ve always known. But if you use them to melt castles and burn cities, you’re not different. You’re just more of the same.”

7x05

Jon meets Drogon, and he and Dany admire the dragons as they fly away.

Dany: “They’re beautiful aren’t they.”

Jon: “That wasn’t the word I was thinking of, but–”

Jon: “–But yes. They are.”

7x06

Jon and Jorah discuss the death of Jeor Mormont.

Jorah: “Were with him at the end?”

Jon: “I was a prisoner of the wildlings. But we avenged him. I want you to know that every mutineer found justice.”

Jon attempts to give Longclaw to Jorah because he is the most considerate sweetheart in all of Westeros.

Jon: “Your father gave me this sword. He changed the pommel from a bear to a wolf, but it’s still Longclaw. Lord Commander Mormont thought you’d never come back to Westeros. But you are back, and it’s been in your family for centuries. It’s not right for me to have it.”

Jorah doesn’t give it to him, and thank god for that. Because no one else would look this good wielding it:

Jon and Beric talk about being resurrected and their purpose in life.

Beric: “Death is the enemy. The first enemy, and the last.”

Jon: “But we all die.”

Beric: “The enemy always wins. And we still need to fight him. You and I won’t find much joy while we’re here, but we can keep others alive.”

7x07

Jon defends himself for telling the truth to Cersei, and in doing so, comes up with the quote of the season.

Tyrion: “I’m pleased you bent the knee to our Queen. I would have advised it, had you asked. But have you ever considered learning how to lie now and then. Just a bit?”

Jon: “I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers, only better and better lies.”

SWOON.

Jon, Jorah, Dany and co. discuss travel arrangements.

Jon: “It’s your decision your grace. But if we’re going to be allies in this war, it’s important for the northerners to see us as allies. If we sail for White Harbour together, I think it sends a better message.”

Theon expresses admiration for Jon.

Theon: “You’ve always known what was right. Even when we were all young and stupid. You always knew. Every step you take…it’s always the right step.”

Jon: “It’s not. It may seem that way from the outside. But I promise you it’s not true.”

Jon forgives Theon.

Jon: “Our father was more of a father to you than yours ever was. And you betrayed him. You betrayed his memory.”

Theon: “I did.”

Jon: “But you never lost him. He’s a part of you. Like he’s a part of me.”

Theon: “But the things I’ve done—”

Jon: “It’s not my place to forgive you for all of it. But what I can forgive, I do. You don’t need to choose. You’re a Greyjoy, and you’re a Stark.”

———

That’s it, the sum of my efforts. I may have missed a couple, since I was often distracted by The PrettyTM. The final tally, including the two infamous quotes that seem to have become so meaningful in some quarters? 

27

Make of that what you will. Now if you’ll excuse me, I’m off to look at Jon Snow’s butt, which is a far better use of my time.

——

* By way of explanation for the blissfully ignorant uninitiated, there’s a theory (exclusive to tumblr) proposing that Jon is feigning his love and loyalty to Dany. Now, I don’t have an otp. However, this notion irritates me in the extreme because it mostly hinges on very uncharitable assessments of Kit’s acting, not to mention the egregious warping of Jon Snow’s noble character.

This business of Jon using the word ‘but” has to be one of the biggest reaches of them all. Supporters of the theory connect Jon remembering that Ned Stark thought that “everything before the word ‘but’ was bullshit” with what Jon said when he pledged to Daenerys: “I’d bend the knee, but–.” At that point in the scene he looks down at his own naked and injured body. To most of us, he is wordlessly explaining his inability to physically get up and kneel before Dany. To a certain corner of the fandom, it means that he has no intention of pledging allegiance to her; that, as a call back to Jon’s comment about Ned, everything before the word “but” was a lie. 

Yes. Yes, I hear you. I’m tired too.

Now, onward! Oh and credit to @kitsn0w for the gorgeous gif of Jon ducking Drogon and the last one of Jon’s glorious bum. The other crappy gifs are my sad attempts.

7x01

Addressing Tormund about the Wall.

Jon: “I’m not the king of the freefolk, but if we’re going to survive this winter together—”

Tormund: “You want us to man the castles for you?”

Jon argues against Sansa’s proposed punishment of the Karstark and Umber children.

Jon: “My father said, the man who passes the sentence should swing the sword, and I have tried to live by those words. But I will not punish a son for his father’s sins, and I will not take a family home away from a family it has belonged to for centuries.”

After the tension in the great hall, Sansa and Jon argue yet again.

Jon: “You are my sister, but I am king now.”

Sansa (mocking): “Will you start wearing a crown?”

Jon: “When you question my decisions in front of the other lords and ladies, you undermine me.”

Sansa: “So we can’t question your decisions?”

Jon: “Of course you can, but–”

Sansa: “Joffrey never let anyone question his authority. You think he was a good king?”

7x02

Jon receives a summons to Dragonstone (from Tyrion on behalf of Daenerys).

Sansa (to Davos): “You’re not suggesting Jon meet with her!”

Davos: “No, too dangerous.”

Jon: “But?”

Davos: “If the army of the dead make it past the wall, do we have enough men to fight them?”

Jon explains to the northern/vale nobility why he has to go to Dragonstone.

Sansa: “This isn’t an invitation, it’s a trap.”

Jon: “It could be. But I don’t believe Tyrion would do that.”

Even Lady Lyanna Mormont urges him not to go. Look at how sad this makes him!

Jon: “You all crowned me your king. I never wanted it. I never asked for it. But I accepted it because the north is my home. It is a part of me and I will never stop fighting for it, no matter the odds. But the odds are against us. None of you have seen the army of the dead. None of you. We can never hope to defeat them alone. We need allies – powerful allies. I know it’s a risk. But I have to take it.”

7x03

Tyrion reflects on Jon’s decision to come to Dragonstone.

Tyrion: “General rule of thumb: Stark men don’t fare well when they travel south.”

Jon: “True. But I’m not a Stark.”

Drogon: 

Jon and Davos meet with Daenerys.

Davos: “You could storm King’s Landing tomorrow and the city would fall. Hell, we almost took it, and we didn’t have dragons.”

Tyrion: “Almost.”

Jon: “But you haven’t stormed King’s Landing. Why not? The only reason I can see is that you don’t want to kill thousands of innocent people. It’s the fastest way to win the war, but you won’t do it. Which means, at the very least, you’re better than Cersei.”

Jon still won’t bend the knee

Jon: “I mean no offense, Your Grace. But I don’t know you.”

(rest behind a cut, because Jon says “but” a LOT.)

Jon: “It’s not. It may seem that way from the outside. But I promise you it’s not true.”

Jon forgives Theon.

Jon: “Our father was more of a father to you than yours ever was. And you betrayed him. You betrayed his memory.”

Theon: “I did.”

Jon: “But you never lost him. He’s a part of you. Like he’s a part of me.”

Theon: “But the things I’ve done—”

Jon: “It’s not my place to forgive you for all of it. But what I can forgive, I do. You don’t need to choose. You’re a Greyjoy, and you’re a Stark.”

———

That’s it, the sum of my efforts. I may have missed a couple, since I was often distracted by The PrettyTM. The final tally, including the two infamous quotes that seem to have become so meaningful in some quarters? 

27

Make of that what you will. Now if you’ll excuse me, I’m off to look at Jon Snow’s butt, which is a far better use of my time.

——

* By way of explanation for the blissfully ignorant uninitiated, there’s a theory (exclusive to tumblr) proposing that Jon is feigning his love and loyalty to Dany. Now, I don’t have an otp. However, this notion irritates me in the extreme because it mostly hinges on very uncharitable assessments of Kit’s acting, not to mention the egregious warping of Jon Snow’s noble character.

This business of Jon using the word ‘but” has to be one of the biggest reaches of them all. Supporters of the theory connect Jon remembering that Ned Stark thought that “everything before the word ‘but’ was bullshit” with what Jon said when he pledged to Daenerys: “I’d bend the knee, but–.” At that point in the scene he looks down at his own naked and injured body. To most of us, he is wordlessly explaining his inability to physically get up and kneel before Dany. To a certain corner of the fandom, it means that he has no intention of pledging allegiance to her; that, as a call back to Jon’s comment about Ned, everything before the word “but” was a lie. 

Yes. Yes, I hear you. I’m tired too.
trail.content_abstract:
every time Jon Snow said the word “but”in S7

If you don’t know why this is relevant, well, lucky you.

I’ve been doing a season 7 re-watch just for entertainment purposes, but (!) in light of recent ~discourse~ I decided to take note of the times Jon said the word “but.” This was a stretch for me. It’s not the but(t) I’m usually interested in when it comes to Jon Snow. And yet, I soldiered on. You can all thank me later. 

Now, onward! Oh and credit to @kitsn0w for the gorgeous gif of Jon ducking Drogon and the last one of Jon’s glorious bum. The other crappy gifs are my sad attempts.

7x01

Addressing Tormund about the Wall.

Jon: “I’m not the king of the freefolk, but if we’re going to survive this winter together—”

Tormund: “You want us to man the castles for you?”

Jon argues against Sansa’s proposed punishment of the Karstark and Umber children.

Jon: “My father said, the man who passes the sentence should swing the sword, and I have tried to live by those words. But I will not punish a son for his father’s sins, and I will not take a family home away from a family it has belonged to for centuries.”

After the tension in the great hall, Sansa and Jon argue yet again.

Jon: “You are my sister, but I am king now.”

Sansa (mocking): “Will you start wearing a crown?”

Jon: “When you question my decisions in front of the other lords and ladies, you undermine me.”

Sansa: “So we can’t question your decisions?”

Jon: “Of course you can, but–”

Sansa: “Joffrey never let anyone question his authority. You think he was a good king?”

7x02

Jon receives a summons to Dragonstone (from Tyrion on behalf of Daenerys).

Sansa (to Davos): “You’re not suggesting Jon meet with her!”

Davos: “No, too dangerous.”

Jon: “But?”

Davos: “If the army of the dead make it past the wall, do we have enough men to fight them?”

Jon explains to the northern/vale nobility why he has to go to Dragonstone.

Sansa: “This isn’t an invitation, it’s a trap.”

Jon: “It could be. But I don’t believe Tyrion would do that.”

Even Lady Lyanna Mormont urges him not to go. Look at how sad this makes him!

Jon: “You all crowned me your king. I never wanted it. I never asked for it. But I accepted it because the north is my home. It is a part of me and I will never stop fighting for it, no matter the odds. But the odds are against us. None of you have seen the army of the dead. None of you. We can never hope to defeat them alone. We need allies – powerful allies. I know it’s a risk. But I have to take it.”

7x03

Tyrion reflects on Jon’s decision to come to Dragonstone.

Tyrion: “General rule of thumb: Stark men don’t fare well when they travel south.”

Jon: “True. But I’m not a Stark.”

Drogon: 

Jon and Davos meet with Daenerys.

Davos: “You could storm King’s Landing tomorrow and the city would fall. Hell, we almost took it, and we didn’t have dragons.”

Tyrion: “Almost.”

Jon: “But you haven’t stormed King’s Landing. Why not? The only reason I can see is that you don’t want to kill thousands of innocent people. It’s the fastest way to win the war, but you won’t do it. Which means, at the very least, you’re better than Cersei.”

Jon still won’t bend the knee

Jon: “I mean no offense, Your Grace. But I don’t know you.”

(rest behind a cut, because Jon says “but” a LOT.)
